body:
### Problem:
scroll issue with floating windows and extended grapheme clusters, due to some terminals using legacy grapheme clusters

### Solution
extended workaround in ```print_cell_at_pos()``` to handle these cases as ambiguous-width char.
added option to toggle this on:
```vim
:set tuigraphemefix
```
PR fixes #34410

comment_data.body:
IMO this condition is little weird. The idea seems to be "we don't trust the terminal to handle grapheme clusters, like at all" but then only apply that for single width chars? wouldn't the TUI then be equally untrustful for expected-to-be-doublewidth chars (an unhandled double-width cluster would easily be 4, 6, 7 etc cells wide.).

I'd rather do this as a compatibility flag, and then do this as an opt-in if the user knows their terminal fails at clusters. No need for a lot of extra cursor movements for terminals where unicode is fully supported.

Thanks!!! 

I was thinking maybe the user could create an environment variable? 

And we could add a flag to TUIdata that gets assigned as true if os_getenv finds the variable, 
Then if(tui->grapheme_fix) we run that test. 


This way is disabled by default. 

Or would you implement it as a Lua configurable option?

added option and change the condition, to follow your suggestion.

now only the user can toggle this mode on, and to follow the feedback of @justinmk, once the user toggle this behavior, it will apply only to the known terminal that have this issue.
options are hard to get rid of. I thought we discussed a temporary workaround, not a permanent option.

comment_data.body: `print_cell_at_pos` is called pretty often, surely we don't need to check this in every call? just store it once in `tui_init` or whatever?

@justinmk, @bfredl 
I wrote some tests but I was not able to recreate this issue
in tui_spec.lua I wrote:
```lua
 it('keeps TUI grid in sync for 1-cell multi-codepoint graphemes #34410', function()
    clear()
    local screen = tt.setup_child_nvim({
     '--clean',
     'test/functional/fixtures/utf8_demo.txt',
    }, { cols = 135 })
    api.nvim_open_win(0, false, { relative = 'editor', width = 1, height = 1, row = 1, col = 1 })

    for _ = 1, 200 do
      feed_data('\004') -- C-d
    end

    screen:expect({ any = 'test/functional/fixtures/utf8_demo.txt' })
  end)
```

and i try writing also in float_spec.lua:
```lua
  it('keeps grid in sync for 1-cell multi-codepoint graphemes #34410', function()
    local screen = Screen.new(80, 20)
    local config = { relative = 'editor', width = 1, height = 1, row = 1, col = 1 }
  local winid = api.nvim_open_win(0, false, config)
    command(':e test/functional/fixtures/utf8_demo.txt')
   command('set laststatus=2')
  for _ = 1, 200 do
      feed('<C-d>')    end
  screen:expect({ any = 'test/functional/fixtures/utf8_demo.txt' })
end)
```
both test are not included in this PR because they were failing to reproduce the issue #34410, meaning they were always OK when running.

let me know what i did wrong and how to approach this test, thanks for the help!

in addition, likely this would be difficult to reproduce in the test runner, as our `:terminal` implementation is implemented to have the same idea about cell widths and valid clusters as our TUI:)  If we implement the opt-in workaround as I suggested above I wouldn't worry about tests either.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34410#issuecomment-2962178877 mentions: 

> we need to extend the workaround in `print_cell_at_pos()` to also handle such cases.

Is that viable?

Of the terminals listed in that issue, I would guess that alacritty and wezterm may eventually fix themselves. 

Meanwhile, usually we hardcode workarounds for specific terminals, why would this be an opt-in thing? Would not use an environment variable in any case. Perhaps a global variable ~~like `g:term_foo`~~ `g:termfeatures`

I applied the changes to make it hardcoded for the terminals that have issues as per #34410.
now it should apply to all multi-code points clusters.

there is no opt_in/global variable as for now

while working on this, the behavior shown in #34410, happens for the following terminal as well:
- ansi
- dtterm
- nsterm
- rxvt
- vt100
- vt102
